Award.AwardTitle: Support for students from underrepresented institutions and groups to attend the 2018 Goldschmidt Conference; August 12-17, 2018; Boston, MA
Award.AbstractNarration:
The annual V.M. Goldschmidt Conference plays an important role in introducing young researchers to the world of geochemistry, the geosciences discipline that focuses on the chemistry of the earth and the solar system. This project seeks to increase the participation of members of underrepresented groups at the 2018 Goldschmidt meeting in Boston, MA, with participant support. The proportion of underrepresented minorities in the geosciences in the US is appallingly low, even worse than other STEM fields, and there is a large pool of talented students in small colleges and universities without Ph.D. programs who lack the resources to attend international scientific meetings. For example, over the past decade between 200-300 geoscience PhDs have been awarded each year to US citizens and permanent residents, yet there was not a single year in which more than two African American women or six men received geoscience Ph.D. degrees, and for Hispanics/Latinos the maximum numbers are seven women and eight men, Moreover, there is a large pool of talented students in small colleges and universities without Ph.D. programs, who do not have the resources to attend international meetings. Many of these institutions serve low-income students, and/or first-generation students, which represent a great potential reservoir of talent. International scientific meetings are the primary networking outlet for researchers of all experience levels. For students, these meetings are often the first opportunity to interact with eminent members of the international scientific community. It is hoped that by facilitating their participation in the Goldschmidt Conference, they will be turned on to pursue higher degrees, and will meet researchers who will take them on as mentees (as postdocs or graduate students), thus contributing to the need to increase diversity in the geosciences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project addresses an important Broader Impacts-based issue in the geosciences in the US, the appallingly low participation of under-represented minorities. A recent paper by Bernard and Cooperdock (Nature Geoscience 2018) documented that over the four decades between 1973-2012 there were 12,608 geoscience PhD degrees awarded to US citizens and permanent residents, but out of these there were only 95 awarded to African Americans (<0.8%, averaging <3 per year), 46 to Native Americans/Alaskan Natives (<0.4%, averaging ~1 per year), and 261 to Hispanics/Latinos (~2%, averaging <7 per year). Moreover, over the past decade there have been between 200-300 such PhDs per year, yet there was not a single year with more than six African American men or two African American women, and for Hispanic or Latino men and women the maximum numbers were 8 and 7. Therefore, not only is the participation rate of under-represented minorities in the geosciences embarrassingly low, it has shown negligible improvement over decades. In addition, , the current system for funding students to attend international meetings effectively excludes the vast majority of those enrolled at smaller colleges or universities that lack PhD programs, many of which serve low-income students, and/or first-generation students, representing a potential reservoir of talent that could be a source of increased diversity.

In light of these considerations, the leadership of the Geochemical Society (GS), the primary scientific society dedicated to the field of geochemistry, decided to proactively seek to expand opportunities for underrepresented populations by making the V.M. Goldschmidt Conferences more accessible to such students. This annual conference has become the largest and most influential international geochemistry meeting in the world, bringing together scientists from around the globe to share ideas and present cutting-edge research. Participating students have the opportunity to present their research, receive feedback, and interact with leading scientists from more than 50 countries. Many students report that the Goldschmidt Conference is their first opportunity to interact closely with members of the international geochemical community. It is our belief that this can be a transformative experience for such students that could lead them to a career in the geosciences, which would also be of great benefit to the field, through the addition of talented individuals who would not otherwise have become geoscientists. Our hope is the opportunities afforded by this grant will add needed diversity to the membership of the geosciences community.

Thus the primary objective of this project was to facilitate and encourage attendance at the VM Goldschmidt Conferences by making it more affordable for student attendees who represent under-represented students at U.S. institutions. A longer term goal is to increase geoscientist diversity.

The student travel grant program facilitated the education and training of 21 student award recipients. During the Goldschmidt Conference the students had access to dozens of sessions over the five days, in which they could learn about the latest research in their fields. In order to help them navigate a large international conference, they were paired with a mentor. Each student also had the opportunity to present his or her own research through an oral presentation or poster. Almost all students reported that they received valuable feedback on their research. Students also had opportunities to participate in workshops focused on career development and scientific topics.

Most of the students in this program indicated that their participation was only possible thanks to the grants. Some comments from students: ?Geochemistry is a unique field as it crosses many traditional disciplines. As a young, female, Hispanic geochemist, it was important for me to attend a conference where the science itself was not a minority and the attendees were just as diverse as the research topics.? ? ?This conference was particularly encouraging as it included programming on how to make our field more welcoming to groups typically underrepresented in the sciences. I was pleasantly surprised when a faculty member explicitly mentioned her low-income, first-generation, minority identity during a talk, and that visibility was incredibly encouraging as someone who identifies in the same way.?

From the point of view of the investigators, this project was a great achievement, in that a modest $15,000 investment by NSF along with $15,000 from the Society facilitated attendance by 21 individuals who were members of underrepresented minorities or students at non-research universities.
